utterances: Their 10-20 rule has been adopted by most people as the standard, as a matter of fact.
Yeah, it's great.
It's very preventative and if you look - I'm trained both as an Ellis guard and a Red Cross guard.
And I would say, across the board, Red Cross does all kinds of great things for everybody, but I would say that training with them is fantastic.
And the rescues that we've had to make at public pools - we're really lucky in Portland in that, you know, we really reach out to the communities to teach not only the children but adults.
I've taught lots of adult lessons and children lessons.

And, thankfully, you know, I haven't had to go in after too many adults, but it is, I think, very much about, as you were saying earlier, the proper equipment and the proper training are really - it's a preventative measure rather than a reactive measure is how lifeguards should work, I believe.
All right, Ryan.
Thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Yeah.
Bye-bye.
And here's an email question.
And this is from Alicia(ph) in Colorado.
Could you talk about the warning signs of dry drowning?
Dr. Modell, could you speak to that?
Well, I don't believe dry drowning actually occurs anymore, and yet I believe I'm the individual that introduced that term some 40 years ago.
It was based on some studies that were done in France that were perhaps misinterpreted.

But about five years ago, Dr. Lunetta and I - he's the professor and chairman of Department of Forensic Science, University of Helsinki - published a paper in (unintelligible) medical literature and a book chapter, and looked at - he had, I think 1,700 cases in his file of people who died from drowning.
And we found that in over 98 percent of the time, you could clearly demonstrate that water was aspirated.

If you don't find any evidence of aspiration of water in someone that was thought to have drowned, I believe that they probably died of another cause such as a sudden cardiac arrhythmia resulting in cardiac arrest before they could aspirate water.
So dry drowning is, you think, a myth.
Let me just say that I don't think anyone has ever proven it exists.
And as a matter of fact, at the world congress on drowning in Amsterdam in 2002, in the final recommendations, it was recommended that the term be drop and not use.
All right.
Well, thank you very much for your time today, Dr. Modell.
Thank you.
It's been a pleasure being with you.
Jerome Modell, professor emeritus at the Department of Anesthesiology at the University Forest College of Medicine.
Carol Irwin, thank you also for your time.
Oh, thank you.
It's been a pleasure.
Carol Irwin is assistant professor of health sports sciences at the University of Memphis, co-author, ""Constraints Impacting Minority Swimming Participation.
When we come back, we're going to be talking about - well, if you want to climb the tall oak tree, turn to page 12.
If you want to tumble down an empty well, turn to page 90.
All of you fans of the ""Choose Your Own Adventure"" books, there's now an app for that.
Stay tuned.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Our next guest is a conservative who has a suggestion for President Trump.
He shared that suggestion with Steve Inskeep.
Henry Olsen makes that suggestion in the website American Greatness.
He is a senior fellow at the Ethics and Public Policy Center.
And he proposes that the president address Mexicans and Mexican-Americans on the upcoming Cinco de Mayo holiday.
Mr. Olsen, welcome to our studios.
Thanks for having me.
What do you want the president to say?
I want the president to say that Mexican-Americans are Americans, too, and that their interests are American interests.
And that since most Mexican-Americans are still of the working class, that he should explain to the country what his economic nationalism is and why it will work for all Americans.
Would you remind us why it would be, in your view, that the president needs to say something to Mexicans?

Well, because the president has said a number of things that Mexicans rightfully consider to be insulting such as - with calling many Mexicans rapists and criminals when he declared his candidacy and making other comments during the campaign, especially less so as president - that he considered Mexicans less-than-equal American citizens.
And I think he can address that.
We both had coats, but we lost them all during Hurricane Katrina, and I'm cold natured, and I'm being prepared the best I can.
I freeze, you know.
I don't like the cold weather, so...
Yes, you're used to that central heat, so--and living in a tent, it's rough, you know, so...
A lot of people feel this way.
Beau Gillings(ph) of Bay Saint Louis walks around in a donated winter parka with the fur collar pulled up over his head, even in the daytime.
All the houses in his neighborhood were flatted.
Behind him, there is a refrigerator way up in a tree.
He's been living in a tent for six weeks.
Two nights ago, it was really rough.
I mean, the wind was whipping.
It was making my tent flap, and I was worried about the trees over me.
I didn't know if they was weak enough for this wind and so I got kind of scared.
I didn't sleep the rest of the night.
Mike Sweeney(ph), a volunteer for the Hancock County Emergency Operations Center, says most people would rather brave the cold than go to shelters or trailer parks.
They don't want to leave what--those rubble piles, that we call--rubble piles are people's lives.
They are people's memories, and it's their homes and they're going to do whatever they can to try to stay and recover or protect anything that they can.
So he just tries to help them get along.
County officials have been trying to collect more sleeping bags and foam pads.
They've also been distributing pamphlets at feeding centers, suggesting ways to improvise.

We're trying to educate the public on making mats by using some of the donated clothes and putting them inside of garbage bags or wrapping them in some of this FEMA blue sheeting that they do the deliveries with.
They take scraps of that, put the clothes in it, fold it over, duct tape it and make a sleeping bag.
That'll bring them up off the ground a little bit.
A pair of stockings or panty hose are just as good as a pair of 100-dollar silk long johns.
In the meantime, FEMA is rushing to provide more trailers.
More than half of the 6,000 families in Hancock County that have applied for trailers now have them.
Nellie Oakwin(ph) and her son Ronnie(ph) just got theirs.
Since Hurricane Katrina, they had been living in a big military tent donated by the Russians.
They've been sharing it with their dogs, cats and a bunch of other animals that used to belong to their neighbor.
We had ducks and stuff coming in and out.
Chickens, geese.
Oh, y'all should see them.
Chickens, ducks...
Y'all should come up during the day.
...geeses.
Nellie Oakwin says she used to enjoy camping.
But it's a totally different story when you live it 24-7.
She doesn't think she'll want to sleep in a tent again anytime soon.
No, mm-mm.
I'll pass.
Good night.
Oakwin says there's been an upside to the chilly weather.
Since the hurricane, campers had been plagued by swarms of biting flies.
Now the flies are gone.
Kathleen Schalch, NPR News.
This is NPR News.
Shades of the Cold War.
Russian bombers have been buzzing U.S.
aircraft carriers in the last few days, and Moscow is threatening to point missiles at European countries.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has called recent statements from Moscow reprehensible.
But in Moscow today, Russian President Vladimir Putin repeated his threats.
NPR's Gregory Feifer reports.
Inside a packed Kremlin auditorium, photographers snaps pictures of Vladimir Putin emerging for his last annual news conference as Russian president.
(Speaking in Russian)
Putin is due to step down after a presidential election in less than three weeks but that hasn't stopped him from using his public appearances to fuel Russia's growing confrontation with the West.
Sitting next to his Ukrainian counterpart earlier this week, Putin threatened to direct Russian missiles at Ukraine if it becomes a member of NATO.
